message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Optimization-Based Collision Avoidance
Paper Abstract: This article presents a novel method for exactly reformulating nondifferentiable collision avoidance constraints into smooth, differentiable constraints using strong duality of convex optimization. We focus on a controlled object whose goal is to avoid obstacles while moving in an n-dimensional space. The proposed reformulation is exact, does not introduce any approximations, and applies to general obstacles and controlled objects that can be represented as the union of convex sets. We connect our results with the notion of signed distance, which is widely used in traditional trajectory generation algorithms. Our method can be applied to generic navigation and trajectory planning tasks, and the smoothness property allows the use of general-purpose gradient- and Hessian-based optimization algorithms. Finally, in case a collision cannot be avoided, our framework allows us to find "least-intrusive" trajectories, measured in terms of penetration. We demonstrate the efficacy of our framework on an automated parking problem, where our numerical experiments suggest that the proposed method is robust and enables real-time optimization-based trajectory planning in tight environments. Sample code of our example is provided at https://github.com/XiaojingGeorgeZhang/OBCA.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Strong duality"

Links: [{"title":"Strong duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_duality"},{"title":"Weak duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_duality"},{"title":"Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)"},{"title":"Dual linear program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_linear_program"},{"title":"Slater's condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slater's_condition"},{"title":"Semidefinite programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Farkas' lemma - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farkas'_lemma"},{"title":"Structuration theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structuration_theory"},{"title":"Philomena (soundtrack) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philomena_(soundtrack)"},{"title":"S-duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-duality"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about **strong duality**:

## Definition

Strong duality is a condition in mathematical optimization in which the primal optimal objective and the dual optimal objective are equal.(no content)By definition, strong duality holds if and only if the duality gap is equal to 0.

## When Strong Duality Holds

For convex optimization problems, the duality gap is zero under a constraint qualification condition, which is called strong duality. More specifically, if the primal problem is convex and bounded from below, and there exists a point in which all nonlinear constraints are strictly satisfied (Slater's condition), then the optimal solution to the dual program equals the optimal solution of the primal program; this is the strong duality principle.

## Applications

The strong duality theorem states that if the primal has an optimal solution then the dual has an optimal solution too, and the two optima are equal.(no content)The max-flow min-cut theorem is a special case of the strong duality theorem, and other graph-related theorems can be proved using the strong duality theorem, in particular, Konig's theorem.

Strong duality is a fundamental concept in mathematical optimization, particularly in linear programming and convex optimization, where it enables powerful solution techniques.

## Web Search Results for "Convex Optimization"

Here's what I found about convex optimization:

### Definition
Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

### Key Properties
Every point that is local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems, which is a significant advantage over non-convex optimization.

### Solution Methods
The convex programs easiest to solve are the unconstrained problems, or the problems with only equality constraints, which can be eliminated with linear algebra. For more complex problems:

- For unconstrained (or equality-constrained) problems with a general convex objective that is twice-differentiable, Newton's method can be used and can be mathematically proven to converge quickly.
- Gradient descent is an efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization.
- For problems with inequality constraints, a common way to solve them is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function to the objective function, using interior point methods.

### Applications
Convex optimization can be used to model problems in portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, variations of statistical regression, model fitting, electricity generation optimization, and combinatorial optimization.

### Software Tools
There is a large software ecosystem for convex optimization with two main categories: solvers and modeling tools.

I've completed the web search for "Gradient descent optimization". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Gradient descent is a method for unconstrained mathematical optimization and a first-order iterative algorithm for minimizing a differentiable multivariate function.(no content)The idea is to take repeated steps in the opposite direction of the gradient (or approximate gradient) of the function.

## Variants and Related Methods

Stochastic gradient descent has become an important optimization method in machine learning.(no content)The gradient descent can be modified via momentums (Nesterov, Polyak, and Frank–Wolfe) and heavy-ball parameters, with main examples of such optimizers being Adam, DiffGrad, Yogi, and AdaBelief.(no content)Stochastic gradient descent serves as the most basic algorithm used for training most deep networks today.

## Applications

The technique is used in stochastic gradient descent and as an extension to the backpropagation algorithms used to train artificial neural networks.(no content)When combined with the backpropagation algorithm, it is the de facto standard algorithm for training artificial neural networks.

The search results provide comprehensive information about gradient descent optimization, its variants, and its widespread use in machine learning and neural network training.

Web search results for query: "Convex set"

Links: [{"title":"Convex set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_set"},{"title":"Absolutely convex set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolutely_convex_set"},{"title":"Integrally convex set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrally_convex_set"},{"title":"Talk:Convex set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Convex_set"},{"title":"Convex combination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_combination"},{"title":"Convex hull - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_hull"},{"title":"Convex function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_function"},{"title":"Polar set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_set"},{"title":"Budget set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budget_set"},{"title":"Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_optimization"}]

## Convex Set

A set of points is convex if it contains every line segment between two points in the set.(no content)For example, a solid cube is a convex set, but anything that is hollow or has an indent, such as a crescent shape, is not convex.

### Formal Definition

A subset C of a vector space or affine space over the real numbers is convex if, for all x and y in C, the line segment connecting x and y is included in C. This means the affine combination (1 − t)x + ty belongs to C for all x, y in C and t in the interval [0, 1].

### Examples

The convex subsets of R (the set of real numbers) are the intervals and the points of R. Some examples of convex subsets of the Euclidean plane are solid regular polygons, solid triangles, and intersections of solid triangles.(no content)Some examples of convex subsets of a Euclidean 3-dimensional space are the Archimedean solids and the Platonic solids.

### Properties

A convex set in a real or complex topological vector space is path-connected (and therefore also connected). Additionally, the empty set and the whole space are convex.

### Related Concepts

A set C is strictly convex if every point on the line segment connecting x and y other than the endpoints is inside the topological interior of C.(no content)The convex hull, convex envelope or convex closure of a shape is the smallest convex set that contains it.

Links: [{"title":"Signed distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signed_distance_function"},{"title":"Talk:Signed distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Signed_distance_function"},{"title":"Distance transform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_transform"},{"title":"Ray marching - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_marching"},{"title":"Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance"},{"title":"Total variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation"},{"title":"Support function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Support_function"},{"title":"Signed measure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_measure"},{"title":"Gilbert–Johnson–Keerthi distance algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert-Johnson-Keerthi_distance_algorithm"},{"title":"Metric space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_(mathematics)"}]

I found comprehensive information about signed distance functions. Here's what I found:

## Definition

A signed distance function (SDF) is the orthogonal distance of a given point to the boundary of a set in a metric space, with the sign determined by whether or not the point is in the interior.

## Mathematical Properties

If the boundary of the set has a piecewise smooth boundary, then the signed distance function is differentiable almost everywhere, and its gradient satisfies the eikonal equation.(no content)The signed distance function is thus a differentiable extension of the normal vector field.

## Computation Methods

Algorithms for calculating the signed distance function include the efficient fast marching method, fast sweeping method and the more general level-set method.

## Applications

Signed distance functions are applied, for example, in real-time rendering, such as the method of SDF ray marching, and computer vision.(no content)Signed distance functions exist for many primitive 3D shapes and can be combined using mathematical operations like modulo and booleans to form more complex surfaces. Additionally, uniformly-sampled signed distance fields have been used for GPU-accelerated font smoothing and can also be used for 3D solid modelling.

Web search results for query: "Newton method Hessian optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Newton's method in optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton's_method_in_optimization"},{"title":"Quasi-Newton method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-Newton_method"},{"title":"Gauss–Newton algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gauss–Newton_algorithm"},{"title":"Truncated Newton method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truncated_Newton_method"},{"title":"Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno_algorithm"},{"title":"Hessian matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hessian_matrix"},{"title":"Limited-memory BFGS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited-memory_BFGS"},{"title":"Newton's method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton's_method"},{"title":"Symmetric rank-one - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_rank-one"},{"title":"Compact quasi-Newton representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_quasi-Newton_representation"}]

I've performed a web search for "Newton method Hessian optimization." Here are the key findings:

## Newton's Method Overview

Newton's method assumes that the function can be locally approximated as a quadratic in the region around the optimum, and uses the first and second derivatives to find the stationary point.

## Role of the Hessian Matrix

Hessian matrices are used in large-scale optimization problems within Newton-type methods because they are the coefficient of the quadratic term of a local Taylor expansion of a function.(no content)The Hessian matrix is a square matrix of second-order partial derivatives of a scalar-valued function, and it describes the local curvature of a function of many variables.

## Challenges with Newton's Method

Newton's method does not work if the Hessian is not invertible, which is clear from the very definition of Newton's method, which requires taking the inverse of the Hessian. Additionally, if the Hessian is close to a non-invertible matrix, the inverted Hessian can be numerically unstable and the solution may diverge.

## Computational Alternatives

Computing and storing the full Hessian matrix takes Θ(n²) memory, which is infeasible for high-dimensional functions such as the loss functions of neural nets; for such situations, truncated-Newton and quasi-Newton algorithms have been developed.(no content)The most common quasi-Newton algorithms are currently the SR1 formula, the BHHH method, the widespread BFGS method, and its low-memory extension L-BFGS.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Newton's method assumes that the function can be locally approximated as a quadratic in the region around the optimum, and uses the first and second derivatives to find the stationary point.

## Role of the Hessian Matrix

Hessian matrices are used in large-scale optimization problems within Newton-type methods because they are the coefficient of the quadratic term of a local Taylor expansion of a function.(no content)The Hessian matrix is a square matrix of second-order partial derivatives of a scalar-valued function, and it describes the local curvature of a function of many variables.

## Challenges with Newton's Method

Newton's method does not work if the Hessian is not invertible, which is clear from the very definition of Newton's method, which requires taking the inverse of the Hessian. Additionally, if the Hessian is close to a non-invertible matrix, the inverted Hessian can be numerically unstable and the solution may diverge.

## Computational Alternatives

Computing and storing the full Hessian matrix takes Θ(n²) memory, which is infeasible for high-dimensional functions such as the loss functions of neural nets; for such situations, truncated-Newton and quasi-Newton algorithms have been developed.(no content)The most common quasi-Newton algorithms are currently the SR1 formula, the BHHH method, the widespread BFGS method, and its low-memory extension L-BFGS.

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Trajectory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory"},{"title":"Motor planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Trajectoid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectoid"},{"title":"Motor coordination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motor_coordination"}]

Here's a summary of the web search results for "Trajectory planning":

## Overview

Trajectory optimization is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)The plan is a trajectory from start to goal and describes, for each moment in time and each position in the map, the robot's next action.

## Applications

Trajectory optimization is primarily used in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. Key applications include:

- **Robotic manipulators**: A robotic arm with 7 joints and 7 links (7-DOF) is a redundant system where one cartesian position of an end-effector can correspond to an infinite number of joint angle positions, thus this redundancy can be used to optimize a trajectory to avoid obstacles or minimize torque in the joints.

- **Aerial vehicles**: Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.

- **Kinodynamic planning**: Kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Methods and Algorithms

Path planning is solved by many different algorithms, which can be categorised as sampling-based and heuristics-based approaches.(no content)Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

Web search results for query: "Automated parking vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Automated parking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_parking_system"},{"title":"Automatic parking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_parking"},{"title":"Intelligent Parking Assist System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_Parking_Assist_System"},{"title":"Auto Stacker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auto_Stacker"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Pay-by-plate parking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pay-by-plate_parking"},{"title":"Parking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parking"},{"title":"Parking lot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parking_lot"},{"title":"Advanced driver-assistance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_driver-assistance_system"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_vehicles"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about automated parking vehicles:

## Types of Automated Parking Systems

An automated (car) parking system (APS) is a mechanical system designed to minimize the area and/or volume required for parking cars. There are two main categories:

### 1. Mechanical Parking Facilities
Like a multi-story parking garage, an APS provides parking for cars on multiple levels stacked vertically to maximize the number of parking spaces while minimizing land usage. The APS utilizes a mechanical system to transport cars to and from parking spaces (rather than the driver) in order to eliminate much of the space wasted in a multi-story parking garage.(no content)Fully automated parking systems operate much like robotic valet parking. The driver drives the car into an APS entry area. The driver and all passengers exit the car. When driver and passengers have left the entry area, the mechanical system lifts the car and transports it to a pre-determined parking space in the system.

### 2. Vehicle Automatic Parking (In-car systems)
Automatic parking is an autonomous car-maneuvering system that moves a vehicle from a traffic lane into a parking spot to perform parallel, perpendicular, or angle parking.(no content)Multiple car manufacturers have added limited versions of an Automated Valet Parking (AVP) system to their vehicles. The systems allow a car to park itself in certain parking lots or garages, without a driver in the vehicle.

## Key Examples and Achievements

The largest Automated Parking Facility in the world is in Al Jahra, Kuwait, and provides 2,314 parking spaces.(no content)Mercedes-Benz introduced world's first commercial Level 4 Automated Valet Parking (AVP) system named Intelligent Park Pilot for its new S-Class.

Links: [{"title":"Traffic collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Carrier-sense multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier-sense_multiple_access_with_collision_avoidance"},{"title":"Airborne collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_Ground_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_Access_with_Collision_Avoidance"},{"title":"Maritime Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (networking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(networking)"},{"title":"Collision avoidance in transportation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_in_transportation"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (spacecraft) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(spacecraft)"}]

Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about collision avoidance across multiple domains. Here's an overview:

## General Definition

In transportation, collision avoidance is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

## Key Applications

### Automotive
A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)Collision avoidance systems range from widespread systems mandatory in some countries, such as automated emergency braking (AEB) in the EU, agreements between carmakers and safety officials to make crash avoidance systems eventually standard, such as in the United States, to research projects including some manufacturer specific devices.

### Aviation
A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of MAC.

### Maritime
Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness. These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence, to issue navigational alerts, assess risks, or initiate corrective actions.

### Spacecraft
Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

### Computer Networking
In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of MAC.

### Maritime
Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness. These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence, to issue navigational alerts, assess risks, or initiate corrective actions.

### Spacecraft
Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

### Computer Networking
In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other), wikipedia_url (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

4. **Strong duality** (concept) - Theoretical principle for constraint reformulation
5. **Signed distance function** (concept) - Connection with traditional trajectory generation
6. **Motion planning** (task) - Application area for the framework
7. **Gradient descent** (method) - Optimization algorithm enabled by smoothness
8. **Newton's method in optimization** (method) - Second-order optimization capability
9. **Automatic parking** (task) - Demonstration/validation domain
